text.headline: SC Miscegenation law
text.text:
A.D. 1879

Marriage between a white person and an Indian, Negro, mulatto, mestizo, or half-breed shall be null and void. Penalty: Misdemeanor, $500 fine or imprisoned for not less than a year. Ministers who performed such marriages are subject to the same penalty.

text.headline: Memorandum of Understanding
text.text:
A.D. 1943

Catawba Indians are Federally recognized, and 3400 acres are added to the existing 1840 reservation

text.headline: SC Miscegenation law
text.text:
A.D. 1952

Marriage of white with Negro, mulatto, Indian, or mestizo declared void. Penalty: Not less than $500 and/or not less than 12 mnths imprisonment.

text.headline: Termination of Catawba Reservation
text.text:

text.headline: NAGPRA (Federal Law)
text.text:
A.D. 1990

The Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act describes the rights of Native American lineal descendants, Indian tribes, and Native Hawaii prganizations with respect to the treatment, repatriation, and disposition of Native American human remains, funterary objects, sacred objects, and objects of cultural patrimony, referred to collectively in the statute as cultural items, with which they can show a relationship of lineal descent or cultural affiliation.

text.headline: Catawbas regain Federal Recognition
text.text:
A.D. 1993

Catawbas regain Federal Recognition after a difficult 20 year court battle. They remain the only federeally recognized tribe in SC.

text.headline: Native American Ad Hoc Committee
text.text:
A.D. 2001

First meeting of the Native American Ad Hoc Committee heald at the SC Commission for Minority Affairs. Chiefs and leaders from 16 tribes and tribal groups were in attendance.

text.headline: SC Commission of Minority Affairs
text.text:
A.D. 2003

SC CMA's statute was amended to include Afrrican-Americans, Hispanics, and Native Americans, creating a state point of contact for each.

text.headline: State Recognition Standards
text.text:
A.D. 2004

The SC General Assembly approved new regulations allowing State Recognition of Native Americans .

text.headline: State Recognition Awarded
text.text:
A.D. 2005

The Waccamaw Indian People and the Pee Dee Nation of Upper South Carolina are the first State Recognized SC Tribes. The Eastern Cherokee, Southern Iroquois and United Tribes (ESCUIT) were recognized as a group, as were the Wassamasaw Tribe of Varnertown Indians and the Chaloklowa Chickasaw Indian People .

text.headline: State Recognition Awarded
text.text:
A.D. 2006

Beaver Creek Indians, Pee Dee Indian Tribe of SC and Santee Indian Organization become state recognized tribes. The Piedmont American Indian Association/Lower Eastern Cherokee (PAIA) becomes a state recognized group. The American Indian Chamber of Commerece becomes the first special interest organization to receive state recognion.

text.headline: State Recognition Awarded
text.text:
A.D. 2007

Natchez Indian Tribe and Pee dee Indian Nation of Beaver Creek become state recognized groups.

text.headline: Great Smallpox Epidemic I
text.text:
A.D. 1698

Charleston 1698, a smallpox epidemic so monstrous that the Reverend Hugh Adams, a recently arrived Congregationalist minister from New England, wrote, “The dead were carried in carts, being heaped one upon another. Worse by far than the Great Plague of London, considering the smallness of the town. Shops shut up for six weeks; nothing but carrying medicines, digging graves, carting the dead.” It is thought that this epidemic also entirely eradicated the Wando Indian tribe. (Source Unidentified)
